Paint and Bodywork Process

  • Teardown, Strip

    A quick blow-over can be achieved by just scuffing, taping, and shooting. Perfection means pulling the car apart and down to a bare shell, stripped of the last nut and bolt, and kicking off the paintwork from there.

  • Body Building

    After stripping the car to bare metal, the body build will progress to sheetmetal repair. In the process of a major body restoration such as ours, you will be looking at two basic choices: repair or replace. In the case of bolt-on body panels for which replacements are readily available, it doesn’t take long for the cost of new metal to make economic sense versus the option of repairing the existing panel.

  • Body Alignment

    While replacing individual panels might seem simple enough, the real measure of a quality job is the fit and alignment. Replacement panels will typically need custom work for a perfect result. Often, welding and dolly work are needed to get the lines and gaps perfect. The honest news here is that perfection often involves welding on panel edges to perfect the gap, especially with replacement sheetmetal.

  • Prep and Primer

    If the metalwork and body panel repairs are nicely done, just a very thin skim of polyester body filler will achieve perfection. The initial filler is worked with a sanding block or body file, reapplying filler as needed. Once the repair is satisfactorily feathered-in with the surrounding metal, it can be sanded progressively finer in preparation for the primer-surfacer coat. If sanding alone does not clean the filled surface, another coat of filler or a glaze coat can be applied.

  • Spraying Paint

    Before painting, it is important that the surfaces are totally free of debris and contaminants. Once the base color coat is sufficiently flashed dry, the clear follows. It is a simple step-by-step process. Previously painted areas are carefully masked, and the loose panels racked in the booth.

  • Cutting and Buffing

    The process of cutting and polishing the paint takes it to the next level. To get a show-quality paint finish, the cut and buff process takes the approach perfection. No matter how clean the paint might be, and no matter how skillfully the paint is sprayed, there will be flaws and surface texture. If everything was done to top standards, the texture will be minimal and the paint surface will have very little contamination. A glass-smooth surface with a mirror finish demands just that little bit more.

Need some work done on your ride?

Give us a bit to respond with a detailed estimate. We need time to do a through review to research and write your estimate.

1 Give us your info

Describe what work you'd like done. You'll receive a text and email once we've reviewed your request.

2 Get an Estimate

We'll review the work needed, source parts, and write-up a detailed estimate just for you.

3 Approve and Schedule Drop-Off

You'll receive your individualized estimate via text or email. Once you approve the estimate, we'll book your car in the shop and our team will get to work.

4 Time is Money

Only pay for the time our team is working on your car. We use advanced methods for accurate time tracking to ensure you won't pay extra.

5 Hit the Road

Our certified team will repair your car and get you back on the road. We'll do the work and make sure it's done right.

To ensure a prompt response, please enter your valid phone number and email

Please be patient: It can take a day or 2 for smaller jobs and a few days for more complex requests.
